content:
Sure, here's a market sizing exercise based on the number of subscribers per YouTube channel:

1. Number of YouTube channels: As of 2021, there are over 37 million YouTube channels. Source: Statista (<https://www.statista.com/statistics/1054645/number-youtube-channels-worldwide/>)
2. Percentage of YouTube channels that belong to brands: There is no specific data available on this, so we made an assumption of 20% based on industry knowledge and research.
3. Percentage of YouTube channels that are in English: There is no specific data available on this, so we made an assumption of 60% based on industry knowledge and research.
4. Average number of subscribers per brand YouTube channel: According to a study by Social Blade, the average number of subscribers per YouTube channel is around 41,900. Source: Social Blade (<https://socialblade.com/blog/youtube-statistics/>)
5. Estimated number of brand YouTube channels with more than 100,000 subscribers: We estimated that 10% of brand YouTube channels have more than 100,000 subscribers based on industry research and knowledge.
6. Estimated market size: To calculate the market size, we first need to determine the target market segment. In this case, the target market segment is brand YouTube channels with more than 100,000 subscribers.

TAM (Total Available Market) = Total number of YouTube channels x % of channels belonging to brands x % of channels in English = 37 million x 20% x 60% = 4.44 million

SAM (Serviceable Available Market) = TAM x % of brand YouTube channels with more than 100,000 subscribers = 4.44 million x 10% = 444,000

SOM (Serviceable Obtainable Market) = SAM x average number of subscribers per brand YouTube channel = 444,000 x 41,900 = 18.6 billion

Please note that these are assumptions based on industry knowledge and research, and may not be entirely accurate. Additionally, this market sizing exercise does not take into account other factors such as revenue per subscriber or pricing models for YouTube channel management tools.
